bibl.title: Letter from Helen Duprey Bullock to Javier Malagon, July 11, 1952

div1.p: Bullock inquires if Malagon knows of any organizations in Cuba that are concerned with the preservation of historical monuments, and whether there are any provisions in Cuban law for the protection of such sites. Bullock mentions Hench's interest in the preservation of Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Helen Duprey Bullock to Javier Malagon, July 11, 1952
div1.opener:
Y F
July 11, 1952
Dr. Javier Malagon, Secretario
Instituto Panamericano de Geografia
E Historia
Comision de Historia
Av. Del Observatorio 192
Mexico 18, D. F.
Dear Dr. Malagon:
div1.p:
The two publications on Chile and Panama have been re-
ceived and we are most grateful for them. We should also like to
congratulate you on their typographical excellence. In the current
issue of the quarterly I have mentioned this series, but in the
fall issue would like very much to write more of your program, and
perhaps use an illustration. Would you be willing to lend us a
glossy print photograph of the torreon of the city of Valdivia used
on the cover of the volume on Chile?

One of our members, a distinguished physician, has been
interested in the preservation of Building No. 1 in Lazear, Havana,
Cuba, where Dr. Walter Reed conducted his famous experiments which
led to the conquering of yellow fever. Do you know of any state or
other organization in Cuba which concerns itself with preservation
of historical monuments? Is there any provision in Cuban law for
the protection of such sites or buildings? We would appreciate
having any information which you have available, and if you can
give us the names of individuals in Cuba with whom we could communi-
cate it will be most helpful.

If our early issues of the quarterly are republished, we
shall supply you with them, and will also send you any of our future
publications.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Mrs. Helen Duprey Bullock
Chief, Historical Research HDB:J
cc: Dr. Hench
